This study investigates the influence of particle size of Ziegler-Natta (ZN) catalysts on the micro-structure and properties of related polypropylenes. In this regard, three catalysts were synthesized with different particle sizes (PS) including PS < 25, 25 ≤ PS ≤ 45, and PS > 45 μm, but from the same ingredients. The catalyst characterization involved a wide range of methods including TGA, BET, SEM, EDS, XRD, LPS, and N2 adsorption-desorption techniques. Next, a series of propylene homopolymers and their copolymers with 1-hexene were prepared using the as-synthesized catalysts, in the presence or absence of H2 under similar reaction conditions. The synthesized (co)polymers were characterized with DSC, SSA, 13CNMR and TREF techniques. The activity was found to increase with decreasing catalyst particle size in both homo- and copolymerization experiments. Furthermore, a catalyst with a larger particle size provided a polymer with a lower isotacticity index, slightly longer meso sequence length, and higher 1-hexene content of about 10.57 %. This affirms the importance of catalyst/support particle size control during the preparation process in industrial polypropylene plants. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polypropylene Ziegler-Natta, Comonomer Structure-properties Relationship Particle size Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Polyolefins are the most demanded plastic materials in the world and their global consumption is expected to grow more and more due to the availability of raw materials, the easy production process and new emerging applications [1,2]. It is well established that the polyolefins' micro-structure and their final properties are mainly controlled by the nature and structure of the catalyst used in the polymerization process [3–7]. Among polyolefins, polypropylene (PP) is the second most discarded plastic [8,9], after high-density polyethylene [10–12]. Currently, PP is produced by homogeneous and heterogeneous processes, i.e. by the well-known Ziegler-Natta (ZN) catalyst. However, despite great academic achievements in homogenous catalysis reactions for the production of PP, a significant portion of this polymer is still manufactured by ZN catalysts on a commercial scale [13]. Recent ZN catalysts are generally composed of Ti(IV) precursors, mostly TiCl4 [14,15], adsorbed on a highly disordered MgCl2-type support in the presence of Lewis base compounds, known as electron donors [9,16,17]. The latter compound plays an essential role in controlling the stereoselectivity of isotactic PP (iPP) [18,19]. In addition to chemical variables, the structural characteristics of the ZN catalysts including surface area, porosity, shape, and size influence their performance in propylene/α-olefin copolymerizations towards polymerization kinetics, the H2 response and the comonomer affinity, which constitute the PP microstructure [20,21]. It is worth mentioning that the so-called characteristics can be finely tailored by the type of primary support. Among proposed supports, MgCl2·EtOH has received considerable attention from both industry and academic perspectives. Indeed, modern highly active and selective ZN catalysts are manufactured using that support. A multitude of studies have been conducted to assess the structure–performance relationship of ZN catalysts since their discovery in the mid-20th century [22,23]. However, because of the complicated nano-structure of these catalysts and the interplay of several components in their performance, the acquisition of their structure–performance relationship is still an attractive challenge. It has already been reported that the particle size of polyolefins affects the thermal stability of synthesized PP [24], degree of polymer crystallinity, polymer molecular weight, melt flow index (MFI), and rheological characteristics [25], as well as comonomer incorporation and their distribution within the polyolefin backbone [26,27]. In fact, a balance of tailored molecular weight, tacticity, and branching distributions tunes iPPs final characteristic which is unique to each application. Despite the importance of polymer particle size in tailoring its characteristics [28], the origin of such dependency has not yet been explored. In this regard, we suppose that catalyst particle size can play a decisive role in influencing the final polymer characteristic [29,30]. In recent research to shed light on this issue, three different catalysts were synthesized from the same MgCl2·EtOH type support, but with different particle sizes. Then, their behavior in propylene polymerization and its copolymerization with the comonomer 1-hexene was assessed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials MgCl2, ethanol, TiCl4 (99 %), triethylaluminium (TEAL), diisobutyl phthalate (DIBP), cyclohexyl methyl dimethoxy silane (C-Donor), 1-hexene and silicon oil (with a viscosity of 100 cps) were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. (Germany). Toluene and n-hexane were provided from Bandar Imam Petrochemical Co. (Mahshahr, Iran), distilled over CaH2, and kept over 13 X and 4 Å type activated molecular sieves and sodium wire. Span 80 as an emulsifier was purchased from Fluka, Buchs, Switzerland. Propylene and N2 gases were supplied from Bandar Imam Petrochemical and Roham companies (Iran), respectively, and used as received. Hydrogen (99.99 %) was supplied from Roham company and employed as a chain transfer agent in the polymerization reactions. 2.2 Synthesis of catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of the support According to the procedure used by Rezaeian et al. [17], targeted MgCl2·EtOH adduct, as the support of ZN catalysts, was synthesized using a series of glass reactors. In the first reactor, MgCl2 (5.0 g) was melted and dissolved in 9 mL ethanol (EtOH/MgCl2= 3 mol/mol). Then, 170 mL silicon oil containing 0.5 wt. % of the span 80-emulsifier was injected into the reactor. The stirring was continued for 3 h at 140°C and 1000 rpm. The content of the aforementioned reactor was transferred into the next reactor under vigorous mixing speed, containing hexane as the solvent at −25°C. Finally, the content of the second reactor was evacuated, and then, the solid support was washed out with dry hexane, followed by drying under a N2 atmosphere [17,31]. The prepared adduct was sieved into three fractions including PS < 25, 25 ≤ PS ≤ 45, and PS > 45 μm. The sieved adduct samples were exploited in subsequent catalyst synthesis as described in the following. 2.2.2 Preparation of the catalysts Each of the sieved adduct samples was used for ZN catalyst synthesis, according to the following procedure. TiCl4 (40 mL) was injected dropwise into the 250 mL glass reactor containing 40 mL toluene as a solvent and 2.0 g of the sieved adduct under a N2 atmosphere at −10°C. The reactor was heated slowly to 60°C, at that time DIBP (0.13 mL, donor/Mg=0.12 mol/mol) was injected in one portion, then the temperature was raised to 100°C and kept for 120 min. The solvent above the solid product was filtered out and then the remained solid was reacted again with titanium tetrachloride (40 mL) in toluene (30 mL) at 120°C for 120 min. Then, the reactor was cooled to 90°C, and after the extraction of the remained titanium tetrachloride with filtration, the solid catalyst was washed with hexane, and then it was dried and stored under nitrogen atmosphere. The prepared catalysts using sieved adduct samples with diameter of PS < 25, 25 ≤ PS ≤ 45, and PS > 45 μm, were labeled as Cat-1, Cat-2 and Cat-3, respectively. The synthesized catalysts were characterized with various methods described below and used in propylene homo- and copolymerization reactions. 2.2.3 Propylene homo- and copolymerization reactions Propylene polymerizations were conducted in a 250 mL stainless steel pressurized reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer and heating-cooling controller. After purging the empty reactor with N2 gas at 80°C for 1 h, hexane (100 mL) as a solvent, TEAL as a cocatalyst (Al/Ti = 180 mol/mol), C-Donor (Al/Si= 20 mol/mol), and the as-prepared catalyst (20 mg) were consecutively injected into the reactor at 30°C. The pre-polymerization was initiated by the introduction of the propylene monomer and continued at P= 2 bar for 10 min. After the prepolymerization step, the pressure was reduced to atmospheric pressure by venting the gas above the reactor, the temperature was raised to 70°C and the reactor was charged with 1-hexene comonomer (5 mL), and 3 bar of H2. The pressure of the reactor increased up to 6 bar and was fixed using continuous feeding of propylene monomer. After 50 min, the reactor was cooled to the room temperature and the synthesized polymer was separated by filtration and vacuum dried at 80°C. 2.2.4 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the catalysts was carried out by using a Siemens D-5000 X-ray diffractometer (USA) at 40 kV and 25 mA with a copper target (λ = 1.54 Å) and a scanning rate of 3 min. The results were analyzed by X'pert Highscore Plus software. SEM images of the synthesized catalysts and also EDX analysis and elemental maps were recorded employing an SEM instrument (SEM model S-3000 N, Hitachi, Japan). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was employed to explore thermal stability and determine the EtOH content of the prepared support sample in the range of 25–400°C by utilizing a TGA instrument (Mettler Toledo Inc., Switzerland) under N2 atmosphere and with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The specific surface area of the catalysts was determined through Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) examinations using a BELSORP Mini II instrument. Particle sizes of the synthesized catalyst and their distributions were measured utilizing a Malvern Zetasizer Nano ZS instrument (United Kingdom) according to ISO 13320-2 standard. The DSC thermograms of the synthesized polymer samples were recorded employing DSC Mettler Toledo (Switzerland), under N2 atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The degree of crystallinity (Xc) and melting temperature (Tm) were determined through a second heating scan, and Xc values were calculated using the following formula: (1) X C = Δ H m Δ H m + Where, ΔH+ m is the specific melting enthalpy of 100% crystalline polypropylene (209 J/g) [32] and ΔHm is the specific melting enthalpy of the prepared polymers. The thickness of lamellae and their distribution in the synthesized polymers were analyzed via successive self-nucleation and annealing (SSA) technology. The SSA analysis was carried out by a Mettler Toledo instrument (Switzerland) according to the Müller method [33,34] with the following steps: (I) heating the sample from 50 to 200°C and holding it at this temperature for 5 min to delete thermal history, (II) cooling from 200 to 50°C and holding at this temperature for 5 min, (III) heating from 50°C to Ts=164°C and holding for 5 min, (IV) cooling from Ts=164°C to 50°C, (V) repeating steps (III) and (IV) with new lower Ts, ranging from 164 to 144°C, with ΔTs = 5°C intervals, (VI) finally heating the PP sample from 50 to 200°C. The heating and cooling rate in all runs was 10°C/min. The lamellar thickness was obtained from SSA curves employing the Thomson-Gibbs equation [35]. (2) T m = T m ∘ ( 1 − 2 σ Δ H l c ) Where lc is the lamellar thickness, Tm is the middle temperature of each melt peak at the SSA curve, T°m is the melting point of an infinite PP crystal (460 K) [36,37], ΔH is the heat of fusion of the crystal with an infinite lc (184 × 106 J/m3), and σ is the free energy of the lamellar surface (0.0496 J/m2). To elucidate the chemical composition distribution of polymer samples, a homemade P-TREF (Temperature Rising Elution Fractionation) consisting of a cylindrical steel column with a 7 cm diameter and 40 cm height has been employed, packed with sands with the average diameter of 700 μm. A procedure described by Kebritchi et al. [38] was used to perform the TREF analyses [38,39], packed with sands with the average diameter of 700 μm. This column was submerged in an oil bath equipped with a programmable thermostat to set the temperature at crystallization and elution cycles. In each fractionation run, 600 cc of polymer solution (1 wt. % in xylene containing 0.05 wt. % of irganox 1010 as antioxidant) at 140°C was injected to the column. It was kept at this temperature for 2 hours and then cooled to the room temperature with the rate of 2°C/hr to crystallize. Then the first fraction (xylene soluble) was washed through the column with fresh xylene at room temperature. For the next fraction, column temperature was raised to the desired temperature (here 40°C) at the rate of 0.5°C/min. kept at that temperature for 2 hours and washed with fresh xylene at 40°C. This procedure was repeated for all fractions [39]. 1-hexene content of the copolymers was analyzed by 13CNMR (Bruker Ultrashield AVANCE III400 spectrometer) at 130°C using 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane-d2 and tetramethylsilane as a solvent and reference, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization To unveil the role of catalyst particle size on propylene polymerization, three ZN catalysts with different particle sizes were synthesized. A thorough characterization of the structure of catalysts was performed, in order to unveil their atomic and crystal structure, configuration, morphology, and particle size characteristics utilizing different techniques. Then, their behavior in propylene polymerizations was evaluated in terms of activity, stereo-selectivity, H2 response, and comonomer incorporation which will be discussed in the following. In the first stage, a MgCl2·EtOH-type adduct was prepared according to the procedure described in our recent work [17]. The thermal stability of the prepared support was explored using TGA analysis in the temperature range of 25-400°C (Fig. 1 ). According to the TGA curve, the first weight loss started at 75°C and was attributed to the ethanol evaporation. Furthermore, the second weight loss was observed at 150°C, correlated to the presence of span 80 in the composition of the support sample, as evidenced in the work of Rezaeian et al. [17]. Moreover, the prepared support sample showed a weight loss in the range of 150–190°C, and also at 250°C, which could be related to the desorbed ethanol from the non-thermally treated MgCl2/EtOH. Employing the TGA curve, the ethanol content of 44 wt. % was obtained for the support sample equal to the molar composition of MgCl2·1.6 EtOH. The particle size and its distribution of the prepared adduct obtained via LPS analysis are depicted in Fig. 2 . According to the recorded data, a particle size in the range between 10 and 111 μm with an average value of 37 μm was achieved for the synthesized MgCl2·EtOH adduct. The cumulative particle size curve is also shown in Fig. 2. According to this curve, D10, D50, and D90 values of 17, 37, and 68 μm, respectively, were achieved for the synthesized adduct. D10, D50, and D90 mean that 10, 50, and 90 % of the particles have less than or equal to the corresponding particle diameter, respectively. Moreover, the span value of 1.39 μm was achieved which is relatively narrow and represents homogeneity in the particle size. The prepared adduct was fractioned using appropriate sieves into 3 parts with the diameters of PS < 25, 25 < PS < 45, and PS ≥ 45 µm. These fractions were employed individually in the synthesis of ZN catalyst under similar reaction conditions, and labeled as Cat-1, Cat-2, and Cat-3, respectively. Table 1 lists the atomic composition of the catalysts obtained from the elemental analysis of EDX. All three catalysts had almost similar atomic compositions. However, Cat-1 had a slightly smaller content of Cl and Mg. The titanium and carbon loading values of the catalysts were 2.8 and 16 %, respectively, which are acceptable values for ZN catalysts. It is worth mentioning that the C atom is almost representative of both the internal donor, i.e. DIBP, and remaining ethanol in the composition of the as-synthesized catalysts. To investigate the distribution of Ti atoms on the catalyst surface, EDX mapping of samples was conducted. Fig. 3 discloses that Ti atoms are distributed homogeneously on the surface of the synthesized catalysts. The morphology of the prepared catalyst samples was studied by SEM analysis. In the SEM pictures of Fig. 3, the spherical morphology was evidenced, which was expected for the MgCl2 particles prepared under the mentioned conditions, including vigorous stirring of melted MgCl2 in oil, in the presence of span 80 as an emulsifier that decreases the surface tension of the MgCl2 particles [17]. The spherical catalyst particles subsequently furnish spherical polymer powders, beneficial for easy transport between industrial reactors [9]. The results of the structure and particle size properties for the synthesized catalysts are summarized in Table 1. According to the recorded data, D10, D50, and D90 values of 10, 20, and 28 μm respectively were obtained for the Cat-1 representing a relatively narrow distribution of particle sizes for this sample. Also, for the Cat-2 and Cat-3 samples, a narrow distribution of the particle sizes was achieved with D50 of 37 and 55 μm, respectively. These values confirm that the synthesis protocol was successfully applied to furnish the final catalysts with different D50 and a narrow span, in accordance with our objective considered in this study. The XRD patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . In all XRD patterns, the peaks centered at 2θ angles of 15-16° (corresponding to the Cl–Mg–Cl triple layers along the crystallographic direction), 30-35 and 50° (demonstrating the presence of (104) and (110) planes, respectively) could be observed. These peaks approve the proper crystalline structure of the furnished catalysts, according to the literature [20,40,41]. Furthermore, the existence of a distinctive peak at 16° (representative of the (003) plane) in the XRD pattern of the three catalysts indicates that the catalysts’ crystallites contain more than 10 Mg-Cl-Mg layers [20,40]. Additionally, in the XRD pattern of all synthesized catalysts the structure of α- and β-MgCl2 could be identified from the peaks in the 2θ = 30-35° region. Specifically, two peaks at 32 and 34° are assigned to the (011) plane of β-MgCl2 (with hexagonal close packing, hcp) and (104) plane of α-MgCl2 (with cubic close packing, ccp), respectively. The structural features of the synthesized Ziegler-Natta catalysts obtained from XRD patterns are given in Table 2 , including the d-spacing, full width at half-maximum (FWHM), crystallite size, and intensity of peaks at 2θ = 15, 35, and 50°. The mentioned peaks are representative of (003), (104), and (110) planes, in the MgCl2 structure, respectively. It is clear that in all catalysts the intensity of peaks at 2θ = 35° is much higher than those at 15° and 50°, which affirms a higher share of (104) surface in comparison to (003) and (110) planes. The crystallite size of the (104) plane (related to the peak at 2θ = 35°) at studied catalysts were similar, i.e. 159.1, 156.2 and 150.5 Å, for Cat-1, Cat-2, and Cat-3, respectively. In the case of Cat-2, and Cat-3, the crystallite size of the (003) and (110) surfaces are close to each other, i.e. 95.9 vs. 96.1 Å and 91.9 vs. 83.0 Å, respectively. Meanwhile in Cat-1 the crystallite size of the mentioned surfaces are relatively different, i.e. 63.8 vs. 95.9 Å. Moreover, both catalysts revealed similar d-spacing at each 2θ angle, although this feature changed by the variation of the 2θ angle. As indicated, there is no considerable difference between α/β ratios of the three catalysts. Since all catalysts contain DIBP as the internal donor, it donates more stability to the α-form through the zip coordination mode and furnishes catalysts with α/β ratio greater than 1.0 [42,43]. XRD patterns were also used to determine the disordering level of the catalysts by employing the Williamson-Hall equation: (3) β × cos ( θ ) = C × sin ( θ ) + k λ L This equation is commonly used to model the broadening [44,45]. β, λ, k, and L in the above equation denotes the total broadening, wavelength, a constant (around 1), and grain size, respectively. According to this equation, the total broadening of XRD peak(s) originates from two parts, namely stacking disorder in the constituent crystals (denoted by C in the first part of the above equation) and the crystalline size. Thus, by drawing the plot of β × Cos(θ) against Sin(θ) and fitting the best line to the experimental data, the stacking disorder of the grain can be obtained using the slope of the fitted line. Fig. 5 and Table 3 display the Williamson-Hall plot, slope, and intercept for the three catalyst samples, respectively. According to the data, it is obvious that the stacking disorder for all three samples is similar. In addition, the slope of the Williamson-Hall plot for all catalysts is close to zero. This indicates that the catalyst particles have no disordering, thus fragmentation tendency of all samples during polymerization will be negligible even though it is unusual [46]. The porosity of the catalysts was investigated using N2 adsorption-desorption measurements. The pore volume, size, and surface characteristics of the catalysts are presented in Table 4 . Increasing the particle size of the MgCl2·EtOH adduct led to an increase of the average pore diameter of the catalysts from 8.5 to 11.2 nm, for Cat-1 to Cat-3, respectively. Surface area values of 69.5, 61.6, and 47.04 m2/g were obtained for Cat-1, Cat-2, and Cat-3, respectively, following the expected trend. Furthermore, the same value of 0.13 cm3/g was obtained for the total pore volume of all three catalysts while the pore shape of Cat-3 was different from those of Cat-1 and Cat-2. According to N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts in Fig. 6 a, all three catalysts showed a similar amount of hysteresis. Furthermore, Cat-3 had a lower specific surface area (47.0 vs. 69.5 and 61.6 m2/g) but larger pore diameter compared to Cat-1 and Cat-2. These features are indicative of narrow inlet-type pores in Cat-3 and wide inlet-type pores in Cat-1 and Cat-2, respectively. Furthermore, all three catalysts revealed N2 adsorption isotherms of type III, indicative of mesoporous materials. In the related curves, the hysteresis loops are categorized into the H3 type, which is suitable for conical-shaped mesopores, containing nonuniform shapes and sizes [47]. The pore size distribution (PSD) of the catalysts (Fig. 6b), obtained in terms of the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) curve [48,49], indicates an increase in pore diameter from 8.5 to 11.2 nm by changing the catalyst type from Cat-1 to Cat-3. Also, according to Fig. 6b, Cat-1 showed a significantly higher amount of large meso-pores at 11 < rp < 24 nm that can have a direct effect on the catalyst behavior during copolymerization towards comonomer incorporation [50], which will be considered later. 3.2 Polymerization results Table 5 presents the results of polymerization runs conducted using the synthesized catalysts. Three polymerization experiments were accomplished for each catalyst including (i) propylene monomer only, (ii) propylene monomer together with H2 as chain transfer agent, and (iii) propylene and 1-hexene as comonomer in the presence of H2. The data obtained via propylene homopolymerization reactions, denoted by sample codes of P/Cat-1, P/Cat-2, and P/Cat-3, exhibited that the catalyst activity is highly dependent on its particle size so that the activity decreased from 4.2 to 1.0 kg PP/gCat.h by increasing the catalyst particle size from Cat-1 to Cat-3. This result could be correlated to the lower mass transfer limitations in the smaller catalysts. The insertion of H2 as a chain transfer agent to the reaction medium led to enhanced catalyst activity for all three catalysts, similar to the results reported in the previous studies. This result could be attributed to the hydrogenation of latent species formed after 2,1-insertion of propylene monomer [51,52]. This reaction enables the so-called sites to re-enter the catalytic cycle [53,54]. The enhancement of catalyst activity upon the addition of H2 was more pronounced for the catalyst with the largest size, i.e. Cat-3. It should be noted that in the presence of H2, the catalyst activity decreased by increasing the catalyst particle size; in agreement with the trend observed in the absence of H2. Copolymerization data of propylene and 1-hexene in the presence of hydrogen pointed out a marked increase in catalyst activity from 4.2 to 7.3, from 3.1 to 6.1, and from 1.0 to 1.4 kg PP/gCat.h for Cat-1, Cat-2, and Cat-3, respectively. Similar outcomes were observed in our recent article [20], in which copolymerization experiments were conducted using commercial catalysts. In fact, the reduction of polymer crystallinity upon the incorporation of the comonomer in the polymer chain can facilitate diffusions through the polymer mass to the active centers. Meanwhile, in copolymerization experiments, the catalyst activity decreased again with increasing catalyst particle size, consistent with the previous data. Using the Soxhlet extraction technique with heptane solvent, neat polypropylene synthesized in the absence of H2, showed a high isotacticity of 96 % and above, which is typical of ZN catalysts containing diisobutyl phthalate as an internal donor. Table 5 demonstrates that the isotacticity index decreased in the presence of H2, and this reduction was more significant for the copolymerization runs. This result could be connected to an increase in the amorphous content of the copolymers due to comonomer presence. In addition, the higher comonomer content of the copolymers, in the case of larger particle sizes, contributed to the slight decrease in the isotacticity index of the copolymers when catalyst particle sizes increased. The results and diagrams for melting point, crystallization temperature and crystallinity of the (co)polymers, measured using DSC, are shown in Table 5, and Fig. 7 , respectively. According to the DSC curves, all homopolymers revealed Tm in the range of 160-162 °C and Tc in the range of 111-115 °C. As a general rule, by increasing polymer tacticity, both Tm and Tc were enhanced to some extent. Furthermore, all three copolymer samples were found to have a similar melting point of ∼152°C. Notably, besides the main melting point, Tm1, all three copolymers displayed a second melting peak, Tm2, at much lower temperatures. It was observed that with an increase in catalyst particle size, their affinity toward 1-hexene comonomer enhanced. As an important outcome of entering more long chain α-olefin comonomer, melting point and crystallinity of the related copolymers diminished. Table 5 outcomes clarified that the second melting point of the copolymers dropped from 146.6 to 143.1°C and then to 141.9°C when the catalyst mean particle sizes increased from Cat-1 to Cat-2 and then to Cat-3. This indicates a lower crystallite size of the copolymer synthesized with Cat-3, arisen from their higher comonomer content, compared to Cat-2 and Cat-1, as can be seen vide infra. According to the literature, the crystallization of propylene/α-olefin copolymers is associated with the regular crystallization of propylene and the formation of crystal defects as well as stereo defects in the synthesized i-PP. The reduction in melting point and crystallinity of the copolymers could be explained by an increase in crystal defects resulting from the greater amount of comonomer incorporated in the copolymers. It is fundamental to know the comonomer content of the synthesized propylene/hexene copolymers. In this regard, in order to calculate the 1-hexene content the formula suggested by Kissin and Brandolini [55] was considered as the following: [ H ] = 0.33 [ H H H ] + [ H H P ] + [ P H P ] ︸ α − C H 2 23.4 − 23.5 ppm + [ H H H ] + [ H H P ] + [ P H P ] ︸ CH 33.6 − 33.9 ppm + [ H H H ] + [ H H P ] + [ P H P ] ︸ γ − C H 2 35.4 − 35.7 ppm The 13CNMR spectrum of P/Cat-3/H2/C6 copolymer is illustrated in Fig. 8 . The assignment of observed peaks in the 13CNMR spectrum is: 19.5-22.2 (CH3 of PPP-iso), 22.7-23.4 (α-CH2 of PHP and HHP), 27.3-29.0 (CH of PPP-iso), 29-29.8 (β-CH2 of PHP and HHP + CH of HPH), 33.2-33.7 (CH of PHP, HHP and HHH), 35.07-35.5 (γ-CH2 of PHP, HHP and HHH), 43.1-44 (CH2 of tetrads) and 45-47.2 ppm (CH2 of pentads). Using the mentioned formula and considering the surface under area of the peaks, 1-hexene content of 3.23, 6.47 and 10.57 % was calculated for the P/Cat-1/H2/C6, P/Cat-2/H2/C6 and P/Cat-3/H2/C6 samples, respectively. According to these data, large particle size catalyst produces prolylene/hexene copolymer containing higher amount of 1-hexene comonomer, correlated to the larger pore diameter of the pre-catalyst. To evaluate the sequence length distribution of the synthesized PPs and the impact of catalyst particle size in this characteristic, SSA analysis was performed [56,57].The melting diagrams of copolymer samples synthesized in the presence of H2, i.e. P/Cat-1/H2/C6, P/Cat-2/H2/C6, and P/Cat-3/H2/C6 after SSA treatment are shown in Fig. 9 . The melting points I related to each peak are listed in Table 6 . As can be seen from the SSA profiles, multiple melting peaks for the synthesized PPs are obtained which correspond to the melting of crystallites with different meso (or isotactic) sequence lengths, MSL, which causes crystallites with various lamellar thicknesses. These crystallites are formed and annealed at employed Ts. In deep analysis, the SSA curves demonstrate the accumulation of five self-nucleation and annealing steps using Ts values in the range of 164 to 144°C with intervals (ΔTs) of 5°C. The relative content of each Tm peak (n%, obtained by the Origin software), together with its related MSL and L are given in Table 6, as well. Based on the values obtained for n, the dominant melting peak in the copolymers is the 5th Tm. Lc and MSL associated with each melting peak in the SSA graphs are calculated using appropriate formulas indicated in the previous literature [58] and the results are gathered in Table 7 . Notably, by moving from Tm1 to Tm5, the Lc value diminishes due to a decrease in MSL content. Indeed, the chains with lower MSL provide crystallites with higher amounts of defects, resulting in thinner lamellar thicknesses [59]. Additionally, it was revealed that by increasing the catalyst's particle size, the melting enthalpy (ΔHm) of the copolymers dropped from 91.9 to 73.3 J/g, while similar values for Tm, Lc, and MSL were obtained. This result could be attributed to the higher comonomer content of the samples synthesized using Cat-3, demonstrating an increase in the amorphous content of the copolymers. It was correlated with the higher pore diameter of Cat-3 compared to Cat-1 and Cat-2, which facilitates the diffusion of the large 1-hexene comonomer to reach the active growing chain. In the next step, for the in-depth analysis of the data related to the SSA patterns, the statistical parameters of the synthesized polypropylenes, including the arithmetic average and the weighted average isotactic sequence length (MSLn and MSLw, respectively), the arithmetic average Ln, the weighted average Lw, and the amplitude index (I), were investigated as given in Table 7. In line with previous findings, increasing the catalyst's particle size led to copolymers with higher Ln, Lw, MSLn, and MSLw amounts with a more unimodal distribution. This result may be correlated with a higher comonomer content of the copolymers from larger catalysts. The distribution of lamellar thickness of the copolymers is shown in Fig. 10 . Fig. 11 demonstrates the results of the TREF analysis that was employed to assess the chemical composition distribution of the copolymers [60]. Using this method, polymer chains are fractioned based on their crystallinity differences derived from their various comonomer content, as well as various regio and stereo defects. Since the tacticity of the corresponding homopolymers was similar (Table 5), TREF analysis was only performed on copolymer samples. Following the TREF profiles of Fig. 10, the copolymer from the small catalysts, i.e. Cat-1 and Cat-2, displayed a peak value at the elution temperature above 100°C as an indication of PP homopolymer [61]. As demonstrated in the SSA analysis, higher comonomer content and lower stereo regularity (tacticity) of the samples from the largest catalyst, i.e. P/Cat-3/H2/C6, results in their lower crystallinity corresponding to higher fractionation levels at low elution temperatures below 100°C. These findings are in good agreement with the crystallinity results of the samples through SSA. Indeed, the less crystalline polymer (according to the SSA results) with a higher 1-hexene content (according to the 13CNMR analysis) was obtained from the catalyst with larger particle size (Cat-3). This polymer contains a higher amount of low temperature fraction, at 40-70 °C, in TREF analysis. 4 Conclusions In this work, the role of ZN catalyst's particle size in propylene/1-hexene (co)polymerizations was evaluated in terms of catalytic activity, H2 response, polymer isotacticity, and comonomer incorporation. In this line, three ZN catalysts with various particle sizes of PS < 25, 25 ≤ PS ≤ 45, and PS > 45 μm, were synthesized using similar ingredients and procedure. It leads to the formation of catalysts with different particle sizes, and pore texture but similar crystalline structure including α/β ratio, morphology and Ti content. Catalyst activity enhances upon decreasing the catalyst particle size in both homo and copolymerizations. Although the isotactic content of homopolymers from all three catalysts was similar, the homopolymers from larger catalysts revealed higher levels of isotacticity in the presence of H2. Noteworthy, bigger catalyst furnished copolymer with slightly lower isotactic content. Thermally fractioned melting curves obtained from SSA analysis were deconvoluted and transformed into discrete values of MSL, Lc, MSLw/MSLn, and Lw/Ln. According to the results, the copolymer from the largest catalyst showed higher MSLw, MSLn, Lw, and Ln values with slightly narrower amounts of MSLw/MSLn, and Lw/Ln, which contributed to its wider pore. In contrast to the SSA results, that copolymer revealed higher amount of low-temperature soluble fraction, corresponded to its higher comonomer content, according to the 13CNMR spectra. Particularly, it can be observed that a catalyst with a larger particle size yields a copolymer of propylene and hexene with a higher proportion of 1-hexene comonomer. This correlation is attributed to the greater pore diameter of the pre-catalyst. Briefly, the obtained results could successfully correlate the particle size of the ZN catalysts with their main characteristic, i.e. H2-and comonomer-response, quantitatively. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the influence of particle size of Ziegler-Natta (ZN) catalysts on the micro-structure and properties of related polypropylenes. In this regard, three catalysts were synthesized with different particle sizes (PS) including PS < 25, 25 ≤ PS ≤ 45, and PS > 45 μm, but from the same ingredients. The catalyst characterization involved a wide range of methods including TGA, BET, SEM, EDS, XRD, LPS, and N2 adsorption-desorption techniques. Next, a series of propylene homopolymers and their copolymers with 1-hexene were prepared using the as-synthesized catalysts, in the presence or absence of H2 under similar reaction conditions. The synthesized (co)polymers were characterized with DSC, SSA, 13CNMR and TREF techniques. The activity was found to increase with decreasing catalyst particle size in both homo- and copolymerization experiments. Furthermore, a catalyst with a larger particle size provided a polymer with a lower isotacticity index, slightly longer meso sequence length, and higher 1-hexene content of about 10.57 %. This affirms the importance of catalyst/support particle size control during the preparation process in industrial polypropylene plants.
coredata.dc:title: Ziegler-Natta catalyst particle size control in propylene/α-olefin (co)polymerizations
